dear people in the comments:

your reaction to learning that you are more complex than you thought shouldn't be 'ahh yes, I can explain all that I don't understand with God'. There's a range of life currently existing from the simplest (like algae) to the most complex (like us); you can even look at our own cells and trace steps of them becoming more efficient and complex (look up mitochondria, for example). Did God design it all? Maybe they did. Or maybe, like our ancestors who believed lightning to be from God, there are answers beyond your current knowledge that other people are pursuing. I'll stick with those who try to prove their ideas, rather than those who ask you to accept their ideas & not question them too much.

I can learn about the details of evolution until I run into the limit of current knowledge. I can learn about 'God designed it all' for about 30 minutes until I run into 'sorry, you just have to have faith'. I'll be playing in the ocean of knowledge while y'all wade in the kiddie pool.

I believe it is the neurotransmitters' receptors that identify whether the postsynaptic neuron is excitatory or inhibitory. It depends on the kind of receptors.
K+ Chemical dependent channels will open when the neurotransmitters bind to them, thus the outflow of K+, and therefore a negative potential: Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potential (IPSP).
Cl- Channels will allow the same result, with the inflow of Cl-.
Na+ channels will open as a result of the neurotransmitters, and thus the inflow of Na+, and therefore a positive potential: Excitatory Postsynaptic Potential (EPSP).
The Inflow and the Outflow of the Ions depends on their concentration gradient: K+ is more abundant on the inside of the neuron, while Na+ and Cl- are more abundant on the outside.

This is a relatively long message but I hope some people can give me a response because this issue has plagued my whole life. interested to know about the role or non-role of synapses/ dendrites/ neurotransmitters etc during sleep paralysis. It seems to me that during these experiences my brain is a bit like a dysfunctional pinball machine, getting stuck bouncing back n forth in corners others stuck in holes and others in chaotic linear directions back n forth, unable to be released, and returned back to base. its my assumption that this inhibits or ceases the ability for messages to be sent from the brain to the body. There are thousands of frustrated synaptic junctions stuck or frozen in limbo battling & trying to outwit each other, but end up in a frozen scrum with a slippery ball no one can grasp. Meanwhile my body is paralysed and often with restricted breathing, and other seemingly deadly symptoms. There is a fear of impending death, that used to have me distraught and awake in tears. That happened in 1988, I thought I had epilepsy but after tests with a neurosurgeon I was diagnosed with sleep paralysis, including associated symptoms of hypnagogic / painful muscle convulsions stuck & unable to correct, and intense sound hallucinations such as the synapses sounding like maggots munching or cicadas feasting on my grey matter rising to a crescendo and pending self combustion. Before I saw the neurologist I always accepted that unable to speak or call out I would lie helpless and laying there helpless would breath my last.

After his advise to relax my body and just ride it out, the severity of the experience lessened. I fact the noise and pain would continue to build till the extreme pain morphed into an intense exhilaration. The first time I tried this instead of my paralysis resuming to normal pain, it morphed into a wired pain but more exhilaration, this continued to increase. I responded without fighting it, Ryding to reassure myself I couldn't die, so let it take its course. Instead of being overwhelmed I sunk into a meditative humility & and amazingly the experience actually went into a deeper pain transitioning to intense euphoria and climaxing with a massive explosion of white light which found my body/ spirit leave my physical body, & travelling like a rocket, exploding again in white light and floating in outer space in euphoria, floating in a nirvana. The pain still reached a state in which I thought my head woulda surely self combust but instead somehow my spirit fused with what what was happening and I had my first Out of Body experience which was the most euphoric experience I had ever had. I've evolved to learn how to control them to a certain extent, all experiences are unique, some more memorable than others. Though some can still be nightmarish, I don't always OBE. His prescription was epilum and advised that during these painful synaptic crashes to just slow my breath and relax my body. within he brain is what happens during an OBE. The neurostranmiters are subsequently in able of sending messages from the brain to the body in these states. Relaxing your body on return is the only way, fighting it is a battle you can't win it takes forever to return back in your body and it's very painful. When you are finally back and you do actually feel your physical form re-enter and you need to keep your eyes closed because even though your back in bed in your body it takes 5 minutes to be fully integrated back. I've had times when I think I'm back in I open my eyes look around to note I am in my room but a little unsettled then I wave my arms in front of my face and I cannot see my arms because I'm not fully integrated back into my body! I've had the most amazing experiences over the last 30 years and one day I hope to write a book about it and make references to scientific explanations as well as some scientific date from Philosophers such as Sheldrake on morphic resonance which I think has some parallels. Thanks for reading would love to hear your thoughts both positive and negative/ sceptic. Thanks Gary.

Here's what I don't really understand: why does anyone bother calling adrenaline "epinephrine" (and, by extension, noradrenaline "norepinephrine")?

The names are synonymous - they even have the same literal meaning (ad-renal = Latin for "beside the kidney"; epi-nephron = Greek for "atop the kidney", both referring to the adrenal gland where the substance is produced) - but while everyone knows the word "adrenaline", only people who've taken some biology or medicine are familiar with "epinephrine". It just seems like a needless complication to say "epinephrine".
Just a quick little context before the intro. :)

While we're talking about reuptake and drugs, most antidepressants (like Zoloft and Prozac) are Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors, or SSRIs. As the name says, they cause the reuptake of serotonin to be inhibited, leaving it in the synaptic cleft and making you feel less depressed. MDMA (the working ingredient in Ecstasy), on the other hand, causes more serotonin to be produced. This causes greater amounts of serotonin to be released into the synaptic cleft, making you feel ecstatic (hence the name). Users of MDMA may notice that once they've taken a certain amount, taking more won't make the experience any better, this is because the ingredients for the production of serotonin have run out. At that point, taking more will only increase the side-effects and the risk of serotonin syndrome.
